results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 - Black & White
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!” In a first for Cyberthon, if not globally this episode was an interactive TV test pilot experiment. It allowed visitors to the Lounge Café, Melbourne an opportunity to compile sequences from the Cyberthon database from a computer also networked to RMITV studio.

A selection of artworks presented were created by: Ian Haig, Adem Jaffers, Dale Nason, Steve Middleton, Attillio Gangemi, Julian Wong, Misha Hollenbach, Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, Stuart McCormick and DJ Andrew Till (The Visitor).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 8 – Black and White is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow
results.creator_credit: G-O-D/ G=enerator, O=perator, D=estroyer, Adem Jaffers and Frank Peppard
results.brief_description:
Please note, this video may potentially trigger seizures for people with photosensitive epilepsy. Viewer discretion is advised.

Cyberthon V: Spectrum Yellow was broadcast as the third of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Mad Club (Danny Slim, Richard Cheese & Cracko), Christopher Coe (Digital Primate), 2120 (Claude Younge Jnr) and Phuture (Crissie Sievers).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 3 - Yellow is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 - Violet
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 7 – Violet was broadcast as the seventh of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Cyberdada (Troy Innocent & Dale Nason), Phuture (Crissie Seivers and M. Buchanan ‘Equinox Comics’), Stelarc, Theatre TV (Eliza, Mari Giambanco and Julie Turner), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Corruption & Vice (Ju-Ann Lam), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason and Kim Bounds) and Dont Shoot The Messenger (Steve Middleton)

Cyberthon VII: Spectrum 7 – Violet is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

group_works.title: I Don't want to be a bludger

results.title: Forced into images
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description: In Destiny Deacon’s photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds that follows a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood. Deacon’s work often explores cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Indigenous women.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.
description_for_label: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.

results.title: Getting the message
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: Dramatization of the difficulties faced by an illiterate adult in employment and social situations. Suggests that with concern and adequate teaching methods this problem can be overcome. The film highlights the plight of the hundreds of illiterate Australian adults.

results.title: Footscray 1911
